Disease # 6940 - Lymphocytic infiltrate of Jessner

Other Names: Benign lymphocytic infiltration, Jessner disease, Jessner-Kanof syndrome, Benign chronic T-cell infiltrative disorder

Categories: Skin Diseases

This disease is grouped under:

Summary: Lymphocytic infiltrate of Jessner is a skin condition characterized by small, red, bumps on the face, neck, and upper back.[1221][3935] The bumps usually last for several months or longer and can enlarge to create a red plaque.[3935] Typically, there are no other symptoms, although rarely, individuals may experience burning or itching. The symptoms may fluctuate between periods of worsening and periods of improvement.[1221][3935] Some cases of lymphocytic infiltrate of Jessner have been associated with borrelia infection (the bacteria that causes Lyme disease); however, in most instances, the cause is not known. Frequently, no treatment is necessary as the bumps and plaque usually spontaneously disappear.[3935]
